hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.title: Modeling Ideological Salience and Framing in Polarized Online Groups with Graph Neural Networks and Structured Sparsity
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.author:
Hofmann, Valentin  and
Dong, Xiaowen  and
Pierrehumbert, Janet  and
Schuetze, Hinrich
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.paperMotivationText: The increasing polarization of online political discourse calls for computational tools that automatically detect and monitor ideological divides in social media.
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.paperContributionText: The authors introduce a new framework called SLAP4SLIP (Sparse LAnguage Properties for Social LInk Prediction) to detect polarized concepts (in terms of salience and framing) in political subreddits.
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.paperResultsText: They show that their model performs substantially better than ablated baselines. In a qualitative analysis, they also find that loyalty/betrayal, purity/degradation and authority/subversion are most important for polarized framing in the analyzed subreddits. Additionally, based on the learned embeddings of their model, they observe that most subreddits experienced a pronounced shift in their ideological orientation.
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.resourcesOtherText: Reddit Politosphere (Hofmann et al. 2022), DW-NOMINATE scores (Lewis et al. 2021)
hofmann-etal-2022-modeling.semiMLText: graph auto-encoder that predicts links between subreddits
